item.title: Calculus - Series
item.description:
Sequence: 3 - squeeze theorem, con and con theorem, bounded

WHY

  • Making Linear to Discrete.

  • A tool for solving some problems in Physics(TAYLOR POLYNOMIALS, etc.) and some situation.

WHAT

Sequence

Sequences: A list of number written in a definite order ${a_n}_{n = 1}^\infty$

Convergence: $\forall \epsilon, \exist N, \forall n > N, |a_n - l| < \epsilon \rArr a_n \rarr l$ OR $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = L \rArr a_n \rarr L$

E.g. $1/x$: $for \ all \ \epsilon, exist \ N = \frac{1}{\epsilon}, for \ all \ n > N, |a_n - 0| < \epsilon \rArr a_n \ convergent \ to \ 0$

  • Test

    • Bounded by lines: Bounded in both sides + Monotonically increasing or decreasing (the continuous decreasing of distance) = Convergent

      • Bounded in both sides: $\forall n, a_n \leq M$ and $\forall n, a_n \geq N$
      • Monotonically increasing or decreasing: $\forall n, a_n < a_{n+1}$ or $\forall n, a_n > a_{n+1}$

        Note. Identifying between decreasing and non-increasing

    • Bounded by functions (Squeeze Theorem): $a_n \leq b_n \leq c_n \rArr \lim{b_n} = L$

  • Usage

    • Continuity and Convergence theorem: $\lim_{x \rarr L}f \exist, \lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = L \rArr \lim_{n \rarr \infty}f$
      • $f(x): a_n = f(n), \lim_{x \rarr \infty}f = L \rArr a_n \rarr L$
      • $a_n, b_n, d_n \rarr C \rArr \lim{(a^C + b \cdot d)} = (\lim{a})^C + \lim{b} \cdot \lim{d}$

Arbitrary Sequence

  • Arithmetic sequence

  • Geometric progression

Series

Series: the sum of the infinite terms from a sequence (limit the $n$ of partial sum $S_n = \sum_{i = 1}^na_n$ to infinity) “The Intergral of a Sequence”

Convergence: The divergence or convergence of $S_n \lrArr Series$ diverges or converges

  • Test for Series

    • Direct Test
      • Overall elements (Integral Test): $f(x)$ is continuous and $a_n = f(n)$, $\sum a_n \rarr/\nrightarrow C \lrArr \int_1^\infty f(x)dx \rarr/\nrightarrow C$
      • Adjacent elements (Ratio test): $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}|\frac{a_{n + 1}}{a_n}| = l < 1 \rArr$ absolute converge (prove using geometric series) (> 1 - diverge, = 1 - inconclusive)
      • Single elements (Root Test): $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}\sqrt[n]{|a_n|}$
    • Non-direct Test: Compare with another
      • Limit Comparison test: $\sum a_n, \sum b_n > 0, \lim_{n \rarr \infty}\frac{a_n}{b_n} = C \rArr \sum a_n, \sum b_n$ both di/converge.
      • Comparison test(“Squeeze Theorem”): $\sum a_n, \sum b_n > 0, \sum b_n$ converges and $a_n \leq b_n$ $\rArr$ $\sum a_n$ converges, vice versa (con to di, $\leq$ to $\geq$).
        • Absolutely converge $\sum|a_n|$ is converges (Conditionally = the condition is not plug in absolute value): $0 \leq \sum a_n + \sum|a_n| \leq 2 \sum|a_n|$

  • Usage

    • $\sum a_n, \sum b_n$ converge, $\sum a_n + \sum b_n = \sum (a_n + b_n)$ and $\sum Ca_n = C \sum a_n$

  • The relationship of Sequence and Series

    • series $\sum_{n = 1}^\infty$ converges $\rArr$ $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = 0$, or series $\sum_{n = 1}^\infty$ diverges $\rArr$ $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n \neq 0$

      • minus prove: $ S_{n} - S_{n - 1}$
      • integral prove

    • $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = 0$ $\nRightarrow$ series $\sum_{n = 1}^\infty$ converges, e.g. $\sum_{i = 1}^\infty\frac{1}{i} > \ln{(n + 1)}$

Arbitrary Series

  • Geometric Series

  • Alternating Series $\sum(-1)^{n - 1} a_n$

    • $a_{n + 1} \leq a_n, \lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = 0 \rArr \sum(-1)^{n - 1} a_n \rarr C$ (decrease + bounded): $S_{2n} = (a_1 - a_2) + (a_3 - a_4) + \ldots +(a_{2n - 1} - a_{2n}) > 0; S_{2n} = a_1 - (a_2 - a_3) - \ldots - a_{2n} < a_1$, then same as $S_{2n + 1} \rArr$ whether n is odd or even, series converges.

    • Alternating Series Estimation Theorem: As the same way as above, we also could derive that $S_{2n} = (a_1 - a_2) + (a_3 - a_4) + \ldots +(a_{2n - 1} - a_{2n}) > (a_1 - a_2) + (a_3 - a_4) + \ldots; S_{2n} = S_{2n} = a_1 - (a_2 - a_3) - \ldots - a_{2n} < a_1 - (a_2 - a_3) - \ldots$
